title: Bright Future for Astrotourism
paragraph: On Black Fell, looking down on Northumberland's Kielder Water reservoir, a group of people wait in a car park next to a strange wooden building. It looks like it was built in the future. This is Kielder Observatory. It is the center of Britains astrotourism industry. And those who were outside were the lucky ones. Many more had applied for a night of stargazing at the observatory, but there are only a few. Inside, next to a woodburner and under dimmed lights, the astronomer who started the observatory, Gary Fildes, is a former bricklayer with Tarzan hair. He gives a talk to his colleagues. The team talks about the idea of seeing the northern lights, but Fildes is not sure. Instead, they decide to use their big telescopes to see Jupiter and Venus. Later they will see stars such as Capella and Betelgeuse. Another thing to see is the appearance of the International Space Station.

title: Man Falls Just Short in Patriot Game to be 100% French
paragraph: Benjamin Carle is made in France. This is right down to his underpants and socks. However, six Ikea forks, a Chinese guitar and wall paint did not stop him being said to be a '' 100% economic patriot ''. Carle, 26, set out in 2013 to see if it was possible to live using only French made things for ten months, as part of a TV show. The idea came about when Arnaud Montebourg, the Minister for Economic Renewal, asked the public to buy French to save the country's manufacturing sector. The experiment cost Carle his smartphone, television, refrigerator (all made in China ), his spectacles ( Italian ), his morning coffee ( Guatemalan ) and his love for David Bowie music ( British ). His girlfriend, Anas, and his cat, Loon, ( both French ) helped him a lot.

title: Morocco Poised to Become a Solar Superpower
paragraph: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions. It is on the edge of the Sahara Desert and at the center of Morocco’s “Ouallywood” film industry. Now, the trading city is the location for a complex of four linked solar mega-plants, which, alongside hydro and wind, will help provide nearly half of Morocco’s electricity from renewables by 2020 with, it is hoped, some spare to export to Europe. The project is a key plank in Morocco’s ambitions to use its deserts to become a global solar superpower. When the full complex is complete, it will be the largest concentrated solar power plant in the world and the first phase, called Noor 1, will go live in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is less widespread and more expensive than the photovoltaic panels that are now familiar on roofs the world over but it will have the advantage of being able to continue producing power even after the sun goes down.

answer_2: Mirror technology can generate energy at night
answer_3: They will be used alongside solar energy

title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was awakened by a loud explosion that shattered the windows of her apartment balcony and broke the clay pots containing her houseplants. She lived in the central Chelyabinsk area. When she got out of bed, she noticed a large vapor trail in the sky and could hear car alarms from the street below. She said, "I didn't know what was happening. There was a big explosion and then several smaller ones. My first thought was that a plane had crashed." What actually happened was that a ten-ton meteorite had fallen to the ground in a series of fireballs just after sunrise. According to officials, nearly 1,200 people were injured, with over 40 taken to the hospital - mostly due to flying glass that shattered because of the sonic boom produced by the meteorite's fall. No fatalities were reported.

title: Google Introduces its Driverless Car
paragraph: Unveiling a car with a top speed of 25mph, two seats and no pedals or steering wheel might not make much of an impression at a motor show. But Google, in the US, sent a minor earthquake through the car and taxi industries as it unveiled the latest version of its driverless car. The electrically powered vehicle, which Google has begun testing around its headquarters in Mountain View, California, dispenses with all the normal controls, including foot pedals. Instead, it has a smartphone app that summons it and tells it the destination, and a single STOP button mounted between the two front-facing seats in case the occupants need to override the computer.

title: Insects Could be the Planets Next Food Source
paragraph: Crunchy, full of protein and to be found under a rock near you. Insects have long been overlooked as food in all but a handful of places around the world. Now they are crawling closer and closer to our plates. Spring 2013 will see a drive toward removing the yuck factor and putting insects on experimental menus. It will also focus on supermarket shelves. In April, there will be a festival in London, England. The festival is called Pestival 2013 – a Wellcome Trust-backed insect appreciation event. It will have a two-day “pop-up” restaurant by the Nordic Food Lab. It is the Scandinavian team behind the Danish restaurant Noma. title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: For almost 100 years, police and intelligence agencies around the world have used polygraphs as lie detectors. They have helped to find spies and traitors. The polygraph is very popular in the movies, with many scenes showing the guilty sweating profusely as they are hooked up. However, the invention may soon end. Researchers in Britain and the Netherlands have made a breakthrough. They have developed a method that has a success rate of over 70%. It could be used in police stations around the world. Rather than relying on facial tics, talking too much or waving of arms - all seen as signs of lying - the new method involves watching full-body movements to find signs of guilt.

title: Japan Calls Time on Long Hours Work Culture
paragraph: The regulation eight hours in the office is over. The most important work of the day is done; whatever is left can wait until the morning. This is the point many workers would think about heading for the door. Yet, for millions of Japanese employees, the thought of clearing away their desks and being at home in time for dinner is enough to invite accusations of disloyalty to the company. But, after decades of giving companies carte blanche to milk every last drop of productivity from their workforce, a challenge to Japan’s ingrained culture of overwork has come from the government, which is considering making it a legal requirement for workers to take at least five days’ paid holiday a year.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: There are about 50,000 mystery shopping trips every month in the UK, according to the Mystery Shopping Providers Association. Mystery shoppers pretend to be a customer in a store but they are really collecting information on how good or bad its service is. The demand for mystery shoppers is growing because online shopping is becoming more popular. “Retailers are becoming increasingly aware that shoppers who visit a physical store want a service and an experience they can’t get online,” says Simon Boydell, spokesman for Marketforce, which has more than 300,000 mystery shoppers. “Our clients want to know how well their stores are delivering on that experience.”

title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: A nasal spray laced with the '' Love hormone '' oxytocin could help children with autism learn how to deal with social situations better. Scans of children with autistic spectrum disorder showed that a single dose of the chemical made the brain respond better to facial expressions. This could make social interactions feel more natural and fun for the children. The scientists behind the research said a course of oxytocin might make behavioral therapies that are already used to help people with autism learn how to deal with social situations easier. Over time, what you would expect to see is more good social responding, being more interested in interacting with other people, more eye contact, and more ability to talk, said Kevin Pelphrey, a researcher at Yale University.

title: Bangladeshi Organization Delivers a Lesson on Ending Child Labor

They have escaped working in the factories opposite.

title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: nasal spray laced with the ‘Love hormone’ oxytocin could help children with autism learn to handle social situations better, US researchers claim. Scans of children with autistic spectrum disorder showed that a single dose of the chemical improved brain responses to facial expressions, a shift that could make social interactions feel more natural and rewarding for them. The scientists behind the research said a course of oxytocin might boost the success of behavioral therapies that are already used to help people with autism learn to cope with social situations. “Over time, what you would expect to see is more appropriate social responding, being more interested in interacting with other people, more eye contact and more conversational ability,” said Kevin Pelphrey, director of the Child Neuroscience Lab at Yale University.

title: Japan Calls Time on Long Hours Work Culture
paragraph: The rule of eight hours in the office is over. The most important work of the day is done. What is left can be done in the morning. This is the point many people would think about going to the store. Yet, for millions of Japanese employees, the thought of going away their desks and being at home in time for dinner is enough to make people think that they are not nice to the company. But, after years of giving companies carte blanche to milk every last drop of productivity from their workers, a challenge to Japan's culture of overwork has come from the government. The government wants to make it a legal requirement for workers to take at least five days'paid holiday a year.

title: Rwandan Women Whip up Popular Ice Cream Business
paragraph: From all across Rwanda, and even parts of neighboring Burundi, people flock to the southern town of Butare to a little shop called Inzozi Nziza (Sweet Dreams). They come for a taste of the unknown, something most have never tasted – the sweet, cold, velvety embrace of ice cream. Here, at the central African country’s first ice-cream parlor, customers can buy scoops in sweet cream, passion fruit, strawberry and pineapple flavors. Toppings include fresh fruit, honey, chocolate chips and granola. Black tea and coffee are also on sale.

title: Inky the Octopus Escapes from Aquarium
paragraph: n octopus has made a brazen escape from the National Aquarium in New Zealand by breaking out of its tank, slithering down a 50-meter drainpipe and disappearing into the sea. In scenes reminiscent of Finding Nemo, Inky – a common New Zealand octopus – made his dash for freedom after the lid of his tank was accidentally left slightly ajar. Staff believe that in the middle of the night, while the aquarium was deserted, Inky clambered to the top of his glass enclosure, down the side of the tank and traveled across the floor of the aquarium. Rob Yarrell, national manager of the National Aquarium of New Zealand in Napier, said: “Octopuses are famous escape artists. I don’t think he was unhappy with us, or lonely, as octopuses are solitary creatures. But, he is such a curious boy. He would want to know what’s happening on the outside. That’s just his personality.”

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: For almost 100 years, police and intelligence agencies have used polygraphs as lie detectors to help convict criminals or to find spies and traitors. The polygraph is popular in movies, and many dramatic moments show the guilty sweating as soon as they are hooked up. However, the invention may soon fail. Britain and the Netherlands researchers have made a breakthrough, developing a method with over 70% success rate in tests that could be in use in police stations worldwide within a decade. Rather than relying on facial tics, talking too much or waving of arms - all seen as signs of lying - the new method involves tracking full-body movements to look for signs of guilt.

title: Vienna Named World’s Top City for Quality of Life

It could have some spare money to sell to Europe. The project is a plank in Morocco’s plans to use its deserts to become a solar superpower. When the full place is complete it will be the largest concentrated solar power plant in the world, called Noor 1 will go live in November 2015. title: Nepal’s Tiger Population on the Rise
paragraph: Tigers are more common in Nepal than at any time since the 1970s, a new census has shown. This gives conservationists hope that the big cats, whose numbers have been falling for 100 years, can be saved. The number of wild royal bengal tigers in Nepal has increased to 198. This is a 63.6% increase in five years. "This is very good news," said Maheshwar Dhakal, an ecologist with Nepal's national parks and wildlife conservation department. More than 500 cameras were placed in five protected areas and three wildlife corridors to take pictures of the animals. More than 250 experts and conservationists worked on the survey. It cost about £250,000.

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: Will we see a world where drones are used to deliver packages anytime soon? According to Amazon, the answer is yes. However, not everyone agrees. Amazon's vice-president of global public policy, Paul Misener, recently told a congressional hearing that his company would be ready to use drones for deliveries once all the rules were in place. The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) is set to introduce regulations for the commercial use of unmanned aircraft in June 2016. However, the technology still has a long way to go before it can be widely used, and larger drones are not yet approved for use in airspace. The proposed rules state that if drones are going to be used extensively, they must all use different radio frequencies to prevent jamming or hijacking.

title: Bolivians Demand the Right to Chew Coca Leaves
paragraph: International debate with extensive consequences for global drug policy has taken place over the right of Bolivia's native Indian tribes to eat coca leaves, the main ingredient in cocaine. Bolivia has obtained a special exemption from the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, allowing its indigenous people to chew the leaves under special conditions. title: Insects Could be the Planets Next Food Source
paragraph: Crunchy, full of protein and to be found under a rock near you. Insects have long been overlooked as food in all but a handful of places around the world. Now they are crawling closer and closer to our plates. Spring 2013 will see a drive towards removing the yuck factor and putting insects not just on experimental gastronomic menus but also on supermarket shelves. In April, there will be a festival in London, Pestival 2013 – a Wellcome Trust-backed insect appreciation event where the consumption of creepy-crawlies comes high on the agenda. It will feature a two-day “pop-up” restaurant by the Nordic Food Lab, the Scandinavian team behind the Danish restaurant Noma. title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken by an enormous explosion in her central Chelyabinsk flat. Windows broke and clay pots containing her few houseplants were broken. When she got up to look, she saw a huge vapor trail in the morning sky and heard the sound of car alarms from below. "I didn't know what was happening," said Zaglumyonova. "There was a large explosion and then a small explosion. My first thought was that it was a plane crash. "What she had actually seen was the end of a ten-ton meteorite that had crashed into the Earth just after dawn. Officials put the number of people injured at almost 1,200, with more than 40 people taken to hospital. Most of the injuries were caused by glass shattered by the falling meteor. title: Nepal’s Tiger Population on the Rise
paragraph: Tigers are more numerous in Nepal than at any time since the 1970s, a new census shows, giving hope to conservationists who have been fighting to save the big cats for 100 years. The number of wild royal bengal tigers in Nepal has increased to 198, up 63.6% in five years, according to a government study. This is very encouraging, said Maheshwar Dhakal, a national parks and wildlife conservation officer with Nepal. The census was based on pictures taken by more than 500 cameras in five wildlife corridors and three protected areas. More than 250 conservationists and experts took part in the survey, which cost around £250,000.

title: Inky the Octopus Escapes from Aquarium
paragraph: An octopus has escaped from the National Aquarium in New Zealand. It escaped from its tank, slid down a 50-meter drainpipe and disappeared into the sea. Inky – a common New Zealand octopus – escaped after someone left the lid of his tank open. Staff at the aquarium believe that, in the middle of the night, when there was no-one in the building, Inky climbed down the side of the tank and traveled across the floor. Rob Yarrell, national manager of the National Aquarium of New Zealand in Napier, said: “Octopuses are famous for their ability to escape. I don’t think he was unhappy with us, or lonely, because octopuses like to live alone. But, he is such a curious boy. He would want to know what’s happening on the outside. That’s his personality.”

title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken in her flat in central Chelyabinsk by an enormous explosion. The explosion blew in the balcony windows and shattered clay pots containing her few houseplants. When she jumped out of bed she could see a vapor trail hanging in the morning sky and hear the wail of car alarms from the street below. “I didn’t understand what was going on,” said lumyonova. “There was a big explosion and then a series of little explosions. My first thought was that it was a plane crash.” What she had actually witnessed were the death throes of a ten-ton meteorite plunged to Fireballs just after sunrise. Officials put the number of people injured at almost 1 in 200. With more than 40 were taken to hospital. Most as a result of flying glass shattered by the boom created by the meteorite’s descent. There were no reported deaths.

title: Bright Future for Astrotourism
paragraph: On Black fell, looking down on Northumberland’s beautiful Kielder Water reservoir, a group of people wait in a car park next to a strange wooden building. This is Kielder Observatory, the center of Britain’s nascent astrotourism industry. And those waiting outside were the lucky ones. Many more had applied for a night of stargazing at the observatory but numbers are strictly limited. Inside, next to a woodburner and under dimmed lights, the observatory’s founder and lead astronomer, Gary Fildes, a former bricklayer with Tarzan hair, delivers a pep talk to his co-leagues. The team discusses the prospect of seeing the northern lights but Fildes is doubtful. Instead, they decide to train their powerful telescopes on Jupiter and Venus and later to pick out stars such as Capella and Betelgeuse. An additional attraction is the appearance of the International Space Station.

title: Morocco Poised to Become a Solar Superpower
paragraph: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions. It is on the edge of the Desert and at the center of Morocco’s “Ouallywood” film industry. Now, the trading city is the location for a complicated of four linked solar mega-plants, which, alongside Hydro and wind, will help provide nearly half of Morocco’s electricity from renewables by 2020 with, some spare to export to Europe. The project is a key plank in Morocco’s ambitions to use its deserts to become a global solar superpower. When the full complex is complete, it will be the largest concentrated solar power plant in the world. The first phase, called Noor 1, will go live in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is less widespread and more expensive than the photovoltaic panels that are now familiar on roofs the world over but it will have the advantage of being able to continue producing power even after the sun goes down.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: There are approximately 50,000 mystery shopping trips carried out every month in the United States, according to the Mystery Shopping providers Association. More and more spending takes place online, the demand for mystery shoppers is growing. title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: Swedish prisons have for a long time had a reputation around the world. But are the country's prisons a soft option? The head of Sweden's prison and probation service, Nils Oberg, said in November 2013 that four Swedish prisons were to be closed because of a decrease in the number of people in prison. Although there has been no drop in crime rates in Sweden, between 2011 and 2012 there was a 6% drop in the number of people in prison. A similar drop is expected in 2013 and 2014. Oberg said he was surprised by the dip, but said he was optimistic that the reason was to do with how his prisons are run. title: Nepal’s Tiger Population on the Rise
paragraph: Nepal's tiger population has increased to its highest level since the 1970s, according to a recent census. This gives hope to conservationists who have seen the numbers of these big cats declining across South Asia for over a century. The government survey showed a 63.6% rise in the number of wild royal Bengal tigers in Nepal, with a total of 198 tigers identified. The survey used more than 500 cameras in five protected areas and three wildlife corridors, with over 250 conservationists and wildlife experts working on the project, at a cost of around £250,000. paragraph: For nearly a century, police and intelligence agencies all over the world have used polygraphs as lie detectors to help catch criminals or uncover spies and traitors. title: Morocco Poised to Become a Solar Superpower
paragraph: The Moroccan city Ouarzazate is famous for big events. It is located in the desert and at the heart of Morocco's "Ouallywood" film industry. Now, the trading city will be the site of four linked solar mega-plants, which, along with wind and hydro, will provide nearly half of Morocco's electricity by 2020, with some of the remaining being exported to Europe. The project is a key step in Morocco's goal to use its deserts as a world solar superpower. When finished, the full complex will be the world's largest concentrated solar power plant and the first phase, called Noor 1, will start operating in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is less common and more expensive than the photovoltaic panels currently used on roofs worldwide, but it will have the benefit that it can continue to produce power after the sun goes down.

title: The Greek Island Where Time Is Running Out

Before Greece was plunged into financial chaos, the people of this small town in the northern Aegean managed quite well. The few dozen rooms to rent were booked out every summer with people who had heard - by word of mouth - of its spectacular empty beaches, clear seas and fresh seafood. They did their banking at the post office.

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: How far away is it going to be that drones deliver packages? If Amazon is right, it is not far at all. Others are not so sure. If technology advances past this point, it is not a matter of invention; it is a public safety issue. Amazon's vice-president of global public policy, Paul Misener, recently told a congressional hearing that his company would be ready as soon as all the rules were in place. The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) will finally have the commercial use of unmanned aircraft regulations by June 2016. But the technology has a long way to go before then and larger machines aren't airway-legal at all yet - only drones up to 25kg will be covered. The FAA points out in the proposed rules that if you are going to use radio-controlled flying robots, you should use different frequencies so that no one can jam or hijack them.

title: Bolivians Demand the Right to Chew Coca Leaves
paragraph: A big international disagreement has started over the right of Bolivia’s indigenous Indian tribes to chew coca leaves, the main ingredient in cocaine. title: Morocco Poised to Become a Solar Superpower
paragraph: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is on the edge of the Sahara Desert. It is now the center for four linked solar mega-plants. The plants, together with hydro and wind, will give Morocco, in North Africa, nearly half of its electricity from renewable energy by 2020. The project is a key part of Morocco’s plans to use its deserts to become a global solar superpower. When the full complex is complete, it will be the largest concentrated solar power plant in the world. The first phase, called Noor 1, will be ready in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is more expensive than the solar panels that we can see on roofs all over the world but it will be able to produce power even after the sun goes down.

title: Nepal’s Tiger Population on the Rise
paragraph: Tigers are more in Nepal than at any time since the 1970s, a new census has shown. This gives conservationists hope that the big cats can be saved, because they have been dropping across south Asia for 100 years. The number of wild royal bengal tigers in Nepal has increased to 198. This is an increase of 63.6% in the last five years. This is very encouraging, said Maheshwar Dhakal, who works for Nepal's Department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation. The census is based on pictures taken by more than 500 cameras. The cameras were placed in five protected areas and three wildlife corridors. More than 250 people from different groups worked on the survey, which cost about £250,000.

title: Swarthy Blue-Eyed Caveman Revealed
paragraph: DNA taken from the wisdom tooth of a European hunter-gatherer has given scientists a new look at modern humans. This was before farming started. The Mesolithic man lived in Spain around 7,000 years ago. His genetic make-up showed that he had an unusual mix of blue eyes, black or brown hair and dark skin. He was probably lactose intolerant and had more difficulty digesting starchy foods than the farmers who changed the way they ate and lived their lives when they took up tools in the first agricultural revolution.

title: Vienna Named World’s Top City for Quality of Life
paragraph: Vienna is the world's best city to live in, Baghdad is the worst and London, Paris and New York do not even make it into the top 35, according to the World Health Organisation ( WHO ). German-speaking cities dominate the rankings in the 18th Mercer Quality of Life study. Zurich, Munich, Dusseldorf and Frankfurt am Main are also in the top seven. Paris has fallen down the league ten places to 37th, just ahead of London at 39th. This is because of the fact that the city is very susceptible to terrorist attacks. The study looked at social and economic conditions, health, education, housing and the environment. It is used by big companies to see where they should put their offices and factories, and how much they should pay people.

title: Man Falls Just Short in Patriot Game to be 100% French
paragraph: Benjamin Carle is 96.9% made in France, right down to his underpants and socks. Unfortunately, six Ikea forks, a Chinese guitar and unsourced wall paint stopped him being declared a 100% economic patriot, but nobody is perfect. Carle, 26, set out, in 2013, to see if it was possible to live using only French-made products for ten months as part of a television documentary. The idea was triggered by the Minister for Economic Renewal Arnaud Montebourg’s call for the public to buy French to save the country’s industrial production sector. The experiment cost Carle his smartphone, television, refrigerator (all made in China); his spectacles (Italian); his underpants (Moroccan); morning coffee (Guatemalan) and his adored David Bowie music (British). Fortunately, his long-suffering girlfriend, Anaïs, and cat, Loon, (both French) stuck with him.

Carle, 26, set out, in 2013, to see if it was possible to live using only French products for ten months without leaving France. The idea came from the Minister of Economic Renewal Arnaud Montebourg. He called on people to buy French to save the country's industrial production sector. The experiment cost Carle his smartphone, television, refrigerator (all made in China); his spectacles (Italian); his morning coffee (Guatemalan) and his favorite British music (David Bowie). Luckily, his girlfriend, Anaïs, and his cat, Loon, stuck with him through it all.

title: Bolivians Demand the Right to Chew Coca Leaves
paragraph: A major international disagreement has taken place over the right of Bolivia's indigenous Indian tribes to chew coca leaves. Cocaine leaves are the main ingredient in cocaine. Bolivia has been given a special exemption from the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs. This means that its indigenous people are allowed to eat the leaves. Bolivia had argued that the convention was against its new constitution, adopted in 2009. The new constitution says that Bolivia must "protect native and ancestral coca as cultural patrimony" and that coca "is not a dangerous narcotic.

paragraph: Full of protein and can be found under a rock near you. Insects have been overlooked as food in most places around the world for a long time. But now they are coming closer to our plates. title: On the Trail of the Wolf
paragraph: Robert Myslajek stops dead. Between two paw prints on a muddy mountain track, the scientist finds what he is looking for. “Droppings!” he enthuses. Wolf sightings are rare that the sighting of their feces marks a good day, even for a seasoned tracker. But it is getting easier. There are now about 1,500 wolves in Poland. The number has doubled in 15 years. Wolves are – along with the brown bear, the lynx and the wolverine – Europe’s last large predator carnivores. Conservationists from Britain, Germany and the Netherlands are beating a path here to find out how Poland has saved this protected species.

title: Autumn-Born Children Better at Sports Says Study
paragraph: Do you want your child to be good at sports, make the school team and, maybe one day, even compete on the world stage? Well, try to ensure that your would-be Olympian or World Cup winner is born in November or, failing that, in October. A study has found that school pupils born in those months are fitter than everyone else in their class. November- and October-born children emerged as fitter, stronger and more powerful than their peers born in the other ten months of the year, especially those whose birthdays fell in April or June. Dr. Gavin Sandercock, who is from the Center for Sports and Exercise Science at Essex University and led the study, found that autumn-born children enjoyed “a clear physical advantage” over their classmates.

title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: Swedish prisons have long had a reputation around the world for being progressive. But are the country’s prisons a soft option? The head of Sweden’s prison and probation service, Nils Oberg, announced in November 2013 that four Swedish prisons are to be closed due to an “out of the ordinary” decline in prisoner numbers. Although there has been no fall in crime rates, between 2011 and 2012 there was a 6% drop in Sweden’s prisoner population, now a little over 4,500. A similar decrease is expected in 2013 and 2014. Oberg admitted to being puzzled by the unexpected dip, but expressed optimism that the reason was to do with how his prisons are run. “We certainly hope that the efforts we invest in rehabilitation and preventing relapse of crime has had an impact,” he said.

title: Nepal’s Tiger Population on the Rise
paragraph: Tigers are more numerous in Nepal than at any time since the 1970s, a new census has revealed, giving conservationists hope that the big cats, whose numbers have been dropping across south Asia for 100 years, can be saved. The number of wild royal bengal tigers in Nepal has increased to 198 – a 63.6% rise in five years – the government survey showed. “This is very encouraging,” said Maheshwar Dhakal, an ecologist with Nepal’s Department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation. The census is based on the examination of pictures from more than 500 cameras placed in five protected areas and three wildlife corridors. More than 250 conservationists and wildlife experts worked on the survey, which cost about £250,000.

title: Can the US Electric Bike Market Get a Jump Start?
paragraph: When Larry Pizzi first heard about electric bikes nearly 20 years ago, he asked: “Why would anyone want to screw up a bike by putting a motor and batteries on it?” It’s a question that still puzzles traditionalists. Bicycle shops have been slow to stock e-bikes, even though they have been around since the late 1990s. Sales in the US have been modest. Pizzi, who is now CEO of Currie Technologies, the number one seller of e-bikes in the US, believes that’s about to change. Others in the industry agree. Familiar brands including Trek, Raleigh and Specialized all offer electric models and they’re betting the market is about to take off. “We’re on the cusp of mainstream adoption,” Pizzi said. “There are more players entering the category, it seems, with every passing month.”

title: Inky the Octopus Escapes from Aquarium
paragraph: A New Zealand octopus has made a brazen escape from the National Aquarium by breaking out of its tank, running down a 50-meter drain and jumping into the sea. In scenes similar to Finding Nemo, Inky - a common New Zealand octopus - made his escape after the top of his tank was inadvertently left a little ajar. Staff believe that in the middle of the night, while the aquarium was deserted, Inky went down the side of the tank, across the aquarium floor and to the top of his enclosure. The National Aquarium of New Zealand national manager Rob Yarrell said: "Octopuses are famous escape artists. I don't think he was disappointed or lonely because octopuses are solitary animals. He is just such a curious boy. He would want to know what is going on outside. That's just his character."

title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: A "love hormone" nasal spray laced with oxytocin can help children with autism learn to better handle social situations, US researchers say. Scans of autistic children showed that a single chemical dose improved their brain responses to facial expressions, a change that may make social interactions more rewarding and natural for them. The scientists behind the research said a course of oxytocin could increase the success of existing behavioral therapy to help autism patients learn to deal with social situations. "Over time, what you would expect to see is more appropriate social response, more interest in social interaction, more eye contact and more ability to talk to people, "said Kevin Pelphrey, director of the Yale University child neuroscience lab.

title: Nepal’s Tiger Population on the Rise
paragraph: According to a new survey, there are more tigers in Nepal than at any time since the 1970s. The number of big cats has been decreasing in south Asia for 100 years, but conservationists now hope that we can save them. The number of wild royal bengal tigers in Nepal has increased to 198 – a 63.6% increase in five years – the survey showed. “This is very good news,” said Maheshwar Dhakal, an ecologist with Nepal’s Department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation. The survey looked at pictures from more than 500 cameras in five protected areas and three wildlife corridors. More than 250 conservationists and wildlife experts worked on the survey, which cost about £250,000.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: Police and intelligence agencies around the world have, for almost 100 years, used the polygraph, a lie-detector test, to help catch criminals and spies. But, now, researchers in Britain and the Netherlands have developed a new method, which is correct (in tests) over 70% of the time. Police stations around the world might begin using this new method within ten years. It doesn’t monitor movements in the face, talking too much or waving arms – all signs that someone is lying. The new method monitors movements in the whole body, which can show that the person is feeling guilty.

title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken in her flat in central Chelyabinsk by a very big explosion that broke the balcony windows and broken pots containing her houseplants. When she jumped out of bed she could see a huge vapor trail in the morning sky and hear car alarms from the street below. “I didn’t understand what was going on,” said Zaglumyonova. “There was a big explosion and then lots of little explosions. My first thought was that it was a plane crash.” In fact, it was a ten-ton meteorite that fell to Earth in lots of pieces. Almost 1,200 people were injured. More than 40 people were taken to hospital – most of them were hurt by flying glass. There were no deaths.

title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: Swedish prisons have a reputation around the world for being liberal and modern. But are the country’s prisons too soft? The head of Sweden’s prison and probation service, Nils Oberg, said in November 2013 that four Swedish prisons will close because of an “out of the ordinary” drop in the number of prisoners. There has been no fall in crime rates, but, between 2011 and 2012, there was a 6% drop in the number of people in Sweden’s prisons, now a little over 4,500. Oberg said he was confused by the drop in numbers, but hoped that the reason was to do with how his prisons are managed. “We certainly hope that the efforts we put into rehabilitation and into stopping criminals from reoffending has made a difference,” he said.

title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken in her apartment in central Chelyabinsk by a big explosion. The explosion blew in the balcony windows and shattered the clay pots she was in. When she jumped out of bed she could see a big vapor trail hanging in the morning sky. She could hear the car alarms coming from the street below. I did not know what was going on, said Zaglumyonova. There was a big explosion and then a lot of small ones. My first thought was that it was a plane crash. But what she saw was the death of a ten-ton meteorite that hit the Earth in a series of fireballs just after sunrise. Officials put the number of people hurt at almost 1,200. More than 40 people were taken to hospital. Most of them were because of flying glass that was blown off by the sound of the meteorite. There were no deaths yet.

title: Morocco Poised to Become a Solar Superpower
paragraph: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate has a lot of big productions. It is on the edge of the Sahara Desert. It is also the center of Morocco's film industry. Now, the trading city is the location for a complex of four linked solar mega-plants, which will help provide nearly half of Morocco's electricity from renewables by 2020. It is hoped that some of the solar power will be exported to Europe. The project is an important part of Morocco's plan to use its deserts to become a world power. When the full complex is finished, it will be the largest solar power plant in the world. The first part of the project, called Noor 1, will go live in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is less common and more expensive than the photovoltaic panels that are now used on roofs all over the world. It will also have the advantage of being able to keep producing power even after the sun goes down.

title: Swarthy Blue-Eyed Caveman Revealed

paragraph: A car with a top speed of 25mph, two seats and no pedals or steering wheel might not seem like a big deal at a car show. title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: Nasal spray laced with the "Love hortt" oxytocin. The summer-year oxytocin could help children with autism learn to handle social situations better than U.S. scientists claim. Scans of children with autism with autism showed that a single dose of the chemical improved brain responses to expressions. This is a shift that could make social interactions feel more natural and rewarding for them. The scientists behind scientists said a course of oxytocin might boost the success of behavioral problems. These are already used to help people with autism learn to deal with social situations. “Over time what you would expect to see is more appropriate social responding being more interested in interacting with other people more eye contact and more conversational ability,” said Kevin Pelphrey. He is the leader of the Child Neuroscience Lab at Yale University.

title: Vienna Named World’s Top City for Quality of Life
paragraph: Vienna is the world’s best city to live in. Baghdad is the worst and London, Paris and New York do not even make it into the top 35, according to international research into quality of life. German-speaking cities dominate the rankings in the 18th Mercer Quality of Life study. Vienna joined by Zurich, Munich and Frankfurt in the top seven. Paris has tumbled down the league, falling ten places to 37th, just ahead of London at 39th, almost entirely because of the city’s vulnerability to terrorist attacks. The study examined social and economic conditions, health, education, housing and the environment. It is used by big companies to determine where they should locate offices and factories.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: Police and intelligence agencies around the world have, for almost 100 years, relied on polygraphs as lie detectors to help convict criminals or unearth spies and traitors. The polygraph is beloved of the movies, with countless dramatic moments showing the guilty sweating profusely as they are hooked up. But the invention could soon be defunct. Researchers in Britain and the Netherlands have made a breakthrough, developing a method with a success rate in tests of over 70percent that could be in use in police stations around the world within a decade. Rather than relying on facial tics, talking too much or waving of arms – all seen as tell-tale signs of lying — the new method involves monitoring full-body motions to provide an indicator of signs of guilty feelings.

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: How far away are we from a world where drones deliver packages? If Amazon is to be believed, not far at all. Others are not so sure: technical progress past this point isn’t merely a matter of invention; it’s a matter of public safety. Paul Misener, Amazon’s vice-president of global public policy, told a congressional hearing recently that his company would be ready as soon as all the rules were in place. The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) will finally have regulations governing the commercial use of unmanned aircraft by June 2016. But the technology has a long way to go before then and larger machines aren’t airway-legal at all. Only drones up to 25kg will be covered and the FAA points out in the proposed rules that, if you’re going to crowd the skies with radio-controlled flying robots, they had better all be using different radio frequencies that nobody can jam or hijack.

title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken in her flat in central Chelyabinsk by an enormous explosion. It blew in the balcony windows and shattered clay pots containing her few houseplants. When she jumped out of bed she could see a huge vapor trail hanging in the morning sky and hear the wail of car alarms from the street below. “I didn’t understand what was going on,” said Zaglumyonova. “There was a big explosion and then a series of little explosions. My first thought was that it was a plane crash.” What she had actually witnessed were the death throes of a ten-ton meteorite that plunged to Earth in a series of Fireballs just after sunrise. Officials put the number of people injured at almost 1,200, with more than 40 taken to hospital — most as a result of flying glass shattered by the sonic boom created by the meteorite’s descent. There were no reported deaths.

title: Four New Elements Find a Place on Periodic Table
paragraph: Such is the lot of the modern-day chemist: you wait ages for a new element to turn up and then four come along at once. Discovered by researchers in Japan, Russia and the US, the four new elements are the first to be added to the periodic table since 2011, when elements 114 and 116 were included. The new elements, all spectacularly short-lived and highly radioactive, complete the periodic table’s seventh row and render science textbooks around the world out of date.

title: John Lewis Christmas Advertisement 2015: Raising Awareness for Age UK
paragraph: A lonely old man living in a crater on the moon is the unlikely focus of John Lewis’s Christmas 2015 advertisement, as the department store puts a charitable spin on its latest multi-million pound campaign. Amid increasing hype around John Lewis’s seasonal ad, which has come to mark the beginning of the Christmas shopping season for many, the department store will aim to use its profile to raise hundreds of thousands of pounds for the charity Age UK. It will also encourage staff and customers to join up with their local branch of the charity to care for elderly people who might otherwise be alone over the holiday. The retailer has spent £7m on a campaign that ranges from the slick TV ad to a smartphone game and merchandise, including glow-in-the-dark pyjamas, as well as areas decked out like the surface of the moon in 11 stores.

title: Bright Future for Astrotourism
paragraph: On Black Fell, looking down on Northumberland’s beautiful Kielder Water reservoir, a group of people wait in a car park next to a strange wooden building with a minimalist design beamed down from the future. This is Kielder Observatory, the center of Britain’s nascent astrotourism industry. And those waiting outside were the lucky ones. Many more had applied for a night of stargazing at the observatory but numbers are strictly limited. Inside, next to a woodburner and under dimmed lights, the observatory’s founder and lead astronomer, Gary Fildes, a former bricklayer with Tarzan hair, delivers a pep talk to his colleagues. The team discusses the prospect of seeing the northern lights but Fildes is doubtful. Instead, they decide to train their powerful telescopes on Jupiter and Venus and later to pick out stars such as Capella and Betelgeuse. An additional attraction is the appearance of the International Space Station.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: There are approximately 50,000 mystery shopping trips carried out every month in the UK, according to the Mystery Shopping Providers Association, and, because more and more spending takes place online, the demand for mystery shoppers is growing. Mystery shoppers pretend to be a customer in a store but they are really collecting information on how good or bad its service is. “Retailers are becoming increasingly aware that shoppers who are prepared to set foot in a physical store want a service and an experience they can’t get online,” says Simon Boydell, spokesman for Marketforce, which has more than 300,000 mystery shoppers on its books. “Our clients want to measure how well their stores are delivering on that experience.”

title: Swarthy Blue-Eyed Caveman Revealed
paragraph: DNA taken from the wisdom tooth of a European hunter-gatherer has given scientists an unprecedented glimpse of modern humans before the rise of farming. The Mesolithic man, who lived in Spain around 7,000 years ago, had an unusual mix of blue eyes, black or brown hair and dark skin, according to analyses of his genetic make-up. He was probably lactose intolerant and had more difﬁculty digesting starchy foods than the farmers who transformed diets and lifestyles when they took up tools in the ﬁrst agricultural revolution.

title: Morocco Poised to Become a Solar Superpower
paragraph: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used to big productions. It is on the edge of the Desert and at the center of Morocco’s “Ouallywood” film industry. Now, the trading city is the location for four linked solar mega-plants. It will help provide nearly half of Morocco’s electricity from renewables by 2020 and some spare to export to Europe. The project is a key plank in Morocco. It wants to use its deserts to become a global solar superpower. When the full building is complete, it will be the largest solar power plant in the world. The first phase, called Noor 1, will go live in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is less expensive. More expensive than the photovoltaic panels are now familiar on roofs the world over but it will be able to continue producing power even after the sun goes down.

title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: Swedish have long had a reputation around the world for being progressive. But are the country’s prisons a soft option? The head of Sweden’s prison and probation service, Nils Oberg, announced in November 2013 that four Swedish prisons are closed due to a “out of the ordinary” drop in prisoner numbers. There has been no fall in crime rates. However, between 2011 and 2012 there was a 6percent drop in Sweden’s prisoner population, now a little over 4,500. A similar decrease is expected in 2013 and 2014. Oberg admitted to being puzzled by the dip. But he expressed hope that the reason was to do with how his prisons are run. “We certainly hope that the efforts we invest in rehabilitation and preventing relapse of crime has had an impact,” he said.

title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: Swedish prisons have long had a good reputation around the world because of this. But is the prison system a soft option? The head of Sweden's prison and probation service, Nils Oberg, said in November 2013 that four Swedish prisons would be closed because the numbers of prisoners were going down. Although crime rates have not gone down, between 2011 and 2012 the number of prisoners in Sweden went down 6%. There are now a little over 4,500. A similar decline is expected in 2013 and 2014. Oberg said he was not sure why the numbers were so low. He hoped that the reason was to do with how his prisons are run. "We certainly hope that the efforts we make to improve rehabilitation and prevent crime have had an impact,” he said.

title: Morocco Poised to Become a Solar Superpower
paragraph: The Moroccan city of Ouarzazate is used for big events. It is on the edge of the Sahara Desert. The city is the center of Morocco's film industry. Now, the trading city is the location for a complex of four linked solar plants, which, along with wind and hydro, will provide nearly half of Morocco's electricity from renewable energy by 2020. Some of them will be exported to Europe. The project is a key part of Morocco's plan to use its deserts to become a global solar power. When complete, the complex will be the world's largest concentrated solar power plant. The first phase, called Noor 1, will start operation in November 2015. The mirror technology it uses is less common and more expensive than the photovoltaic panels that are already used on roofs all over the world, but it can continue to produce power even after the sun goes down.

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: How far away are we from a world where drones deliver packages? If Amazon is to be believed, not far at all. Others are not so sure: technical progress past this point isn’t merely a matter of invention; it’s a matter of public safety. Paul Misener, Amazon’s vice-president of global public policy, told a congressional hearing recently that his company would be ready as soon as all the rules were in place. The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) will finally have regulations governing the commercial use of unmanned aircraft by June 2016. title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken in her flat in central Chelyabinsk by an enormous explosion that blew in the balcony windows and shattered clay pots containing her few houseplants. When she jumped out of bed she could see a huge vapor trail hanging in the morning sky and hear the wail of car alarms from the street below. “I didn’t understand what was going on,” said Zaglumyonova. “There was a big explosion and then a series of little explosions. My first thought was that it was a plane crash.” What she had actually witnessed were the death throes of a ten-ton meteorite that plunged to Earth in a series of fireballs just after sunrise. Officials put the number of people injured at almost 1,200, with more than 40 taken to hospital – most as a result of flying glass shattered by the sonic boom created by the meteorite’s descent. There were no reported deaths.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: Police and intelligence agencies around the world have, for almost 100 years, relied on polygraphs as lie detectors to help convict criminals or unearth spies and traitors. Researchers in Britain and the Netherlands have made a breakthrough, developing a method with a success rate in tests of over 70% that could be in use in police stations around the world within a decade. title: Bolivians Demand the Right to Chew Coca Leaves
paragraph: major international disagreement with wide-ranging implications for global drugs policy has erupted over the right of Bolivia’s indigenous Indian tribes to chew coca leaves, the principal ingredient in cocaine. Bolivia has obtained a special exemption from the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic Drugs, the framework that governs international drugs policy, allowing its indigenous people to chew the leaves. Bolivia had argued that the convention was in opposition to its new constitution, adopted in 2009, which obliges it to “protect native and ancestral coca as cultural patrimony” and maintains that coca “in its natural state ... is not a dangerous narcotic.”

title: Bright Future for Astrotourism
paragraph: On Black fell, looking down on Northumberland’s beautiful Kielder Water reservoir. It is a group of people wait in a car park next to a strange wooden building. This is Kielder Observatory. It is the center of Britain’s growing astrotourism industry. Those waiting outside were the lucky ones. Many more had applied for a night of stargazing at the observatory but numbers are strictly limited. Inside, next to a woodburner and under dimmed lights, the observatory’s founder and lead astronomer, Gary Fildes, a former bricklayer with Tarzan hair. He delivers a pep talk to his co-leagues. The team discusses the prospect of seeing the northern lights but Fildes is doubtful. Instead, they decide to train their powerful telescopes on Jupiter and Venus and later to pick out stars such as Capella and Betelgeuse. An additional attraction is the appearance of the International Space Station.

paragraph: Tigers are more common in Nepal than at any time since the 1970s, a new census says. It gives conservationists hope that the big cats. title: Inky the Octopus Escapes from Aquarium
paragraph: An octopus named Inky has escaped from the National Aquarium in New Zealand by getting out of its tank, sliding down a 50-meter drainpipe, and disappearing into the sea. Inky, who is a common New Zealand octopus, made his escape when the lid of his tank was left slightly open by accident. The staff believes that Inky climbed to the top of his glass enclosure, then went down the side of the tank and across the floor of the aquarium during the night when there was no one around. Rob Yarrell, the national manager of the National Aquarium of New Zealand, said that octopuses are well-known for their ability to escape. He also said that Inky was not unhappy or lonely, as octopuses prefer to live alone, but rather he was just a curious creature who wanted to explore the outside world.

title: Why You Should Start Work at 10AM
paragraph: Many of us are aware that we don't get enough sleep, but what if the solution was as simple as waking up later? Dr. Paul Kelley, a clinical research associate at Oxford University's Sleep and Circadian Neuroscience Institute, suggested in a speech at the British Science Festival that schools should adjust their starting times to match the natural sleep patterns of their students. This change could lead to improved cognitive performance, better exam results, and healthier students. Sleep deprivation has been linked to several health issues, including diabetes, depression, obesity, and weakened immunity.

title: Insects Could be the Planets Next Food Source
paragraph: Insects are a great source of protein, and they can be found under rocks and other places near you. However, most people around the world have not considered insects as food. But now, there is a growing interest in making insects a part of our regular diet. In the spring of 2013, there will be an event in London called Pestival 2013, which is backed by the Wellcome Trust. The event aims to promote the appreciation of insects, and one of the highlights will be a two-day pop-up restaurant by the Nordic Food Lab, the same team that brought ants to the table at the Claridge's hotel in London in 2012. The goal is to remove the "yuck" factor and make insects a common ingredient in both experimental gastronomy and on supermarket shelves.

title: Google Introduces its Driverless Car
paragraph: Google, a company in the US, recently revealed its newest driverless car at a motor show. This car has two seats, no pedals or steering wheel, and a top speed of 25mph. Although it may not seem impressive, it caused a stir in the car and taxi industries. The electric car, which is currently being tested in Mountain View, California, is controlled by a smartphone app that tells it where to go. There are no normal controls, including foot pedals. The only button in the car is a STOP button, located between the two front-facing seats, in case the passengers need to override the computer.

paragraph: In Butare, a town located in the south of Rwanda, people from all over the country, and even from neighboring Burundi, come to a small shop called Inzozi Nziza (Sweet Dreams). They come to taste something new, something they have never tasted before - the sweet, cold, smooth texture of ice cream. It is the first ice cream parlor in the central African country, where customers can purchase scoops in flavors such as sweet cream, passion fruit, strawberry, and pineapple. title: Man Falls Just Short in Patriot Game to be 100% French
paragraph: Benjamin Carle is 96.9% made in France, from socks to underwear. Unfortunately, six Ikea forks, a Chinese guitar and cheap wall paint couldn't make him a 100% business patriot, but no one is perfect. Carle, 26, set out in 2013 to see if you could live with only French products for ten months as part of a television show. The idea was put forth by economic development minister Arnaud Montebourg, who asked the public to buy French to save the country's industrial production. The experiment cost Carle his smartphone, television, refrigerator (all made in China); his Italian spectacles; his morning coffee (Guatemalan); his underpants (Moroccan) and his British David Bowie music. Fortunately, his long-term girlfriend, Anaïs, and her French cat, Loon, stayed with him.

title: Vienna Named World’s Top City for Quality of Life
paragraph: Vienna is the best city in the world to live in, Baghdad is the worst and London, Paris and New York are not even in the top 35 for quality of life according to an international study. In the 18th Mercer Quality of Life study, German-speaking cities dominate, with Vienna joined by Zurich, Munich, Dusseldorf and Frankfurt in the top seven. Paris has dropped down the league, falling ten places to 37th, just ahead of London at 39th, due largely to the city's history of terrorist attacks. title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: How far do we really get to a world where drones deliver? If Amazon is right, it's not far at all. Others are not so sure: technical progress beyond this point is not just an invention; it is a public security issue. Amazon's vice-president for global public policy, Paul Misener, told a congressional hearing recently that his company will be ready when all the rules are in place. The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) will finally issue regulations in June 2016 on the commercial use of drones. However, the technology still has a long way to go and larger machines are not yet airway-legal, and the FAA's proposed rules only cover drones up to 25kg. The FAA says that if you're going to crowd the skies with radio-controlled flying robots, they should all use different radio frequencies that no one can jam or hijack.

title: Swarthy Blue-Eyed Caveman Revealed

He was probably lactose intolerant and had more difficulty digesting starchy foods than the farmers who took up tools in the agricultural revolution and changed diets and lifestyles.

title: Nepal’s Tiger Population on the Rise
paragraph: Tigers are more numerous in Nepal than at any time since the 1970s, a new census has revealed. This gives conservationists hope that the big cats, whose numbers have been dropping across south Asia for 100 years, can be saved. The number of wild royal Bengal tigers in Nepal has increased to 198 — a 63.6percent rise in five years — the government survey showed. “This is very encouraging,” said Maheshwar Dhakal, an ecologist with Nepal’s Department of National Parks and Wildlife Conservation. The census is based on the examination of pictures from more than 500 cameras placed in five protected areas and three wildlife corridors. More than 250 conservationists and wildlife experts worked on the survey. The survey cost about $350,000.

title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: Swedish prisons have long had a reputation around the world for being progressive. But are the country’s prisons a soft option? The head of Sweden’s prison and probation service, Nils Oberg, announced in November 2013 that four Swedish prisons are to be closed due to an “out of the ordinary” decline in prisoner numbers. There has been no fall in crime rates. However, between 2011 and 2012 there was a 6percent drop in Sweden’s prisoner population, now a little over 4,500. A similar decrease is expected in 2013 and 2014. Oberg admitted to being puzzled by the unexpected dip, but expressed optimism that the reason was to do with how his prisons are run. “We certainly hope that the efforts we invest in rehabilitation and preventing relapse of crime has had an impact,” he said.

title: Bolivians Demand the Right to Chew Coca Leaves
paragraph: Major international disagreement with wide-ranging implications for global drugs policy has erupted over the right of Bolivia’s native Indian tribes. They want to chew Coca leaves, the principal ingredient in cocaine. Bolivia has obtained a special exemption from the 1961 Single Convention on Narcotic drugs, allowing its native people to chew the leaves. Bolivia had argued that the convention was in opposition to its new constitution. It was adopted in 2009, which obliges it to “protect native and ancestral Coca as cultural patrimony” and maintains that Coca “in its natural state ... is not a dangerous narcotic.”

title: On the Trail of the Wolf
paragraph: Robert Myslajek stops dead. Between two paw prints on a muddy mountain track, the scientist finds what he is looking for. “Droppings!” he enthuses. Wolf sightings are so rare that the sighting of their feces marks a good day, even for a seasoned tracker. But it is getting easier. There are now an estimated 1,500 wolves in Poland. The number has doubled in 15 years. Wolves are – along with the brown bear, the lynx and the wolverine – Europe’s last large predator carnivores. Conservationists from Britain, Germany and the Netherlands are beating a path here to find out how Poland has saved this protected species, slandered even in fairy tales.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: Police and intelligence agencies around the world have for almost 100 years relied on polygraphs as lie detectors to help convict criminals or unearth spies and traitors. The polygraph is beloved of the movies with countless dramatic moments showing the guilty sweating profusely as they are hooked up. But the invention could soon be working. Researchers in Britain and the Netherlands have made a breakthrough. They are developing a method with a success rate in tests of over 70 percent. The percent could be in use in police stations around the world within a decade. Rather than relying on facial tics, talking too much or waving of arms, all seen as tell-tale signs of lying ing. title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: How far away are we from a world where drones deliver packages? If Amazon is to be believed, not far at all. The Federal Aviation Authority (FAA) will finally have regulations governing the commercial use of unmanned aircraft by June 2016. title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: Galina Zaglumyonova was woken in her flat in central Chelyabinsk by an enormous explosion that blew in the balcony windows and shattered clay pots containing her few houseplants. When she jumped out of bed she could see a huge vapor trail hanging in the morning sky and hear the wail of car alarms from the street below. “I didn’t understand what was going on,” on no” said Zaglumyonova. “There was a big explosion and then a series of little explosions. My first thought was that it was a plane crash.” What she had actually witnessed were the death throes of a ten-ton meteorite that plunged to Earth in a series of Fireballs just after sunrise. Officials put the number of people injured at almost 1 200, with more than 40 taken to hospital. Most as a result of flying glass shattered by the sonic boom created by the meteorite’s descent. Scientists at Yale have studied the brain chemical oxytocin as a possible treatment for the social impairments caused by autism. This is because it can connect with bonding and trust. The results have been mixed. However, one recent study found no big benefit for youths given the chemical over several days. But Pelphrey said oxytocin might help the brain learn from social interactive. It would work best when used with therapies that encourage people with autism to do more socially, he said.

title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: '' The modern prison service in Sweden is very different from when I joined as a young prison officer in 1978. '' Kenneth Gustafsson is the governor of Kumla Prison in Sweden. However, he does not think the system has gone soft. When I joined, there was a lot of attention on humanity in prisons. Prisoners were treated well. Some might say they were treated too well. But, after a number of high-profile escapes in 2004, we had to make prisons more secure. The Swedes still managed to keep a humane approach to sentencing, even of the most serious offenders : jail terms are usually less than 10 years. Sweden was the first country in Europe to use electronic tags on convicted criminals. Sweden continues to try to reduce short-term prison sentences wherever possible by using community-based punishments, which have been shown to be more effective at reducing the number of people sent to prison.

The condition affects people in different ways, but is generally characterized by social interaction and communication problems. Yale researchers have studied the brain chemical oxytocin as a possible treatment for autism because it plays an important role in trust and bonding. But results have been mixed. One recent study found no significant benefit over several days for youths given the chemical. But Pelphrey said oxytocin might help the brain learn from social interactions, and it would work best when used with autism treatment, he said.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: The polygraph is widely used in the United States in criminal and other cases and for security clearance for the FBI and CIA but is much less popular in Europe. There has been a lot of skepticism in the scientific and legal communities about its reliability. By contrast, the new method developed by the researchers has performed well in experiments. The basic premise is that liars fidget more and so the use of an all-body motion suit – the kind used in films to create computer-generated characters will pick this up. One of the research team Ross Anderson said: “Decades of deception research show that the interviewer will tell truth from lies only slightly better than random.” He said the new method by contrast achieved a reliability rating of over 70percent. But in some tests the team has already achieved more than 80percent. Anderson said, “The takeaway message is that guilty people fidget more and we can measure this robustly.”

title: Autumn-Born Children Better at Sports Says Study
paragraph: The study involved 8,550 children, all between ten and 16, in 26 state schools in Essex. All were tested between 2007 and 2010 on three different fitness measures: lower-body power, stamina and handgrip strength. The results show that a child's month of birth can make "significant" differences in their cardiovascular fitness, muscle strength and speed, all of which can predict how good they will be at sports, where these skills are very important. Performance days at school sports might bear out the findings in time. November-born children were the fittest overall as they had the second strongest and had the most stamina. Those born in October were almost as fit, coming third for power and highest for strength, with December children close behind.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: "We assign different locations to each customer and rotate them so that they never return to the same store within three months," says ABa mystery shopping company Jill Spencer. The turning point for Northumberland came in 2013 when the whole national park, including Hadrian's Wall and Kielder Water and Forest Park, some 1,500 square kilometers, received Dark Sky Park status. title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth
paragraph: The meteorite entered the atmosphere traveling at a speed of at least 33,000mph and broke up into chunks between 18 and 32 miles above the ground, according to a statement from the Russian Academy of Sciences. The event caused panic in Chelyabinsk, a Russian city of one million people to the south of the Ural mountains, as mobile phone networks swiftly became jammed by the volume of calls. Amateur video footage from the area, often peppered with the obscene language of frightened observers, showed the chunks of meteorite glowing more brightly as they approached the moment of impact. The vapor trail was visible for hundreds of miles around, including in neighboring Kazakhstan.

Pullman, writer of the His Dark Materials trilogy, says authors and musicians work in poverty and obscurity for years to bring their work to the level “that gives delight to their audiences and, as soon as they achieve that, the possibility of making a living from it is taken away from them”. title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: “The modern prison service in Sweden is very different from when I joined as a young prison officer in 1978,” says Kenneth Gustafsson, governor of Kumla Prison, Sweden’s most secure jail. However, he doesn’t think the system has gone soft. “When I joined, the focus was very much on humanity in prisons. Prisoners were treated well – maybe too well, some might say. But, after a number of high-profile escapes in 2004, we had to implement changes to make prisons more secure.” The Swedes still managed to maintain a broadly humane approach to sentencing, even of the most serious offenders: jail terms rarely exceed ten years. Sweden was the first country in Europe to introduce the electronic tagging of convicted criminals and continues to strive to minimize short-term prison sentences wherever possible by using community-based punishments, which have been proven to be more effective at reducing reoffending.

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: Professor Sanjiv Singh, who runs a cargo delivery company called NearEarth, said that piloting a state-of-the-art drone was a little more like leaving it a trail of breadcrumbs: go to this altitude, perform this short task, go back home. But even short flights from a mobile landing pad pose serious logistical problems, he said. “They’re not proposing to deliver from one uninhabited place to another uninhabited place; they’re proposing to deliver from a warehouse to where the consumer is, which is likely an urban area,” he said. “There are going to be hazards along the way that the vehicle is going to have to detect. Maybe there will be terrain that the map doesn’t know about. Even then, maybe there’s construction equipment that wasn’t there but is there now. Maybe GPS signals are blocked, in which case it’s going to have an incorrect idea about where it is.” All this is surmountable, he said – but it’s difficult.

title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: Autism is a disorder that one in 100 people have. It affects people in different ways, but causes difficulties in social interaction and communication. So far, there is no effective treatment for the social problems that autism causes. Researchers at Yale have studied the brain chemical oxytocin. They say it is a possible treatment for the social problems caused by autism because it plays an important role in bonding and trust. But not all results are positive: one recent study found no significant benefit for young people who took the chemical for several days. But Pelphrey said oxytocin might help the brain learn from social interactions; it would work best when used together with therapies that encourage people with autism to interact more socially, he said.

title: Japan Calls Time on Long Hours Work Culture
paragraph: Japanese employees are allowed an average of 18.5 days’ paid holiday a year, fewer than the global average. title: John Lewis Christmas Advertisement 2015: Raising Awareness for Age UK
paragraph: After two years of successful ads featuring cuddly animals, a bear and hare, then a penguin – this time. The retailer is tugging at the heartstrings with a story of a young girl, Lily, who spots an old man living in a shack on the moon through her telescope. The child tries sending him a letter and firing a note via bow and arrow. Then he floating him a present of a telescope tied to balloons, which finally enables them to make contact. The ad’s strapline is: “show someone they’re loved this Christmas,” which echoes Age UK’s own campaign: “No one should have no one at Christmas.” “The charity really resonates with people at this time of year and the ad lends itself to thinking about someone who lives on your street that might not see anybody,” said Rachel Swift. She is head of marketing at John Lewis.

title: On the Trail of the Wolf
paragraph: The scientist says wolves can move up to 30 kilometers during a single hunt. “The pack that he is tracking is a strong group of eight or nine animals. title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: “The modern prison service in Sweden is very different from when I joined as a young prison officer in 1978,” says Kenneth Gustafsson, governor of Kumla Prison, Sweden’s most secure jail. “When I joined, prisoners were treated well – maybe too well. title: Autumn-Born Children Better at Sports Says Study
paragraph: The research involved 8,550 boys and girls from 26 state schools in Essex between ten and 16. All were tested between 2007 and 2010 on three different fitness measures: lower-body power, stamina and handgrip strength. The results showed that a child's month of birth could make "important" differences in their cardiovascular fitness, muscle strength and ability to speed up. All of these factors predict how good someone is at sports, where these features are important. Results at school sports days in the weeks ahead may support this finding. November-born children were the fittest overall. They had the most power and stamina, and were the second strongest. Those born in October were almost as fit. They scored highest for strength and came third for power, after December children.

title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: Autism is a developmental disorder. About one in 100 people have it. The condition affects people in different ways, but they all have problems with social interaction and communication. So far, there is no effective treatment for autism social problems. Scientists at Yale have studied the brain chemical oxytocin as a possible treatment for autism because it plays an important role in trust and bonding. However, results have been mixed. One recent study found no significant benefit over several days for the chemical. But Pelphrey said oxytocin might help the brain learn from social interactions. It would work best when people with autism are encouraged to socialize more, he said.

title: Inky the Octopus Escapes from Aquarium
paragraph: One theory is that Inky slid across the aquarium floor – a journey of three feet feet and then sensing freedom was at hand into a drainpipe that led directly to the sea. The drainpipe was 50 meters long and opened onto the waters of Hawke’s Bay on the east coast of New Zealand’s North Island. Another possible escape route could have involved Inky squeezing into an open pipe at the top of his tank which led under the floor to the drain. “When we came in the next morning and his tank was empty I was really surprised,” said Yarrell, who has not launched a search for Inky. “The staff and I have been pretty sad. But then this is Inky and he’s always been a bit of a surprise octopus.”

title: Insects Could be the Planets Next Food Source
paragraph: In March a BBC documentary will feature food writer Stefan Gates searching out and eating deep-fried locusts and barbecued tarantulas. However, behind all the gimmicks and jokes about flies in the soup, there is a deeply serious message. Many experts believe there is a clear environmental benefit to humans eating creepy-crawlies. The UN’s Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has been funding projects since 2011 aimed at promoting the eating and farming of insects in south-east Asia and Africa. There, an estimated two billion people already eat insects and caterpillar larvae as a regular part of their diet. In 2012 the FAO published a list of 1,909 edible species of insect and sponsorship from the Dutch government plans a major international conference on “this valuable food source” in 2013.
