title: Wealth Therapy for the Rich
paragraph: “I shifted towards it naturally all” he said of his becoming an expert on wealth therapy. “Many of the extremely wealthy – the 1percent of the 1percent – feel that their problems are really not problems. But they are. So a lot of therapists do not give enough weight to their issues.” So what issues are America’s 1percent struggling with? “There is guilt over being rich in the first place place,” he said. “There is the feeling that they have to hide the fact that they are rich. And, then there is the isolation – being in lonel, it turns out can be lonely.” It seems F. Scott Fitzgerald was right. The very rich “are different from you and me.” Counselors argue things have become worse since the financial crisis and the debate over income inequality that has been spurred on by movements like Occupy Wall Street and the Fight for $15 fair wage campaign.

title: John Lewis Christmas Advertisement 2015: Raising Awareness for Age UK
paragraph: After two years of successful ads featuring cuddly animals – a bear and hare, then a penguin this time, the retailer is tugging at the heartstrings with a story of a young girl Lily who spots an old man living in a shack on the moon through her telescope. The determined child tries sending him a letter and firing a note via bow and arrow before floating him a present of a telescope tied to balloons, which finally enables them to make contact. The ad’s strapline is: “show someone they’re loved this Christmas” which echoes Age UK’s own campaign: “No one should have no one at Christmas.” Profits from three products – a mug, gift tag and card – will go to the charity. “The charity really resonates with people at this time of year and the ad lends itself to thinking about someone who lives on your street that might not see anybody,” said Rachel Swift, head of marketing at John Lewis.

title: Bright Future for Astrotourism

The most important moment for Northumberland came in 2013 when the whole national park with Hadrians Wall, along with Kielder Water and Forest Park, some 1,500 square kilometres, was made a Dark Sky Park, the only one in England. Dark Sky Parks are very rare. The 2013 Star Count showed that only 5% of people in the UK can see more than 31 stars on a good night. The International Dark-Sky Association (IDA ) gives the status only to places that take big steps to avoid light pollution ( see below ). They must also prove that their night skies are dark enough. title: Bangladeshi Organization Delivers a Lesson on Ending Child Labor
paragraph: For 14 years, SOHAY has been working in slum areas of Dhaka to get child laborers into school. It is a non-governmental organization ( NGO ) funded by the Global Fund for Children and Comic Relief. It is about children working in dangerous places. They work in aluminum and plastic factories and tanneries. It is one of 23 urban development centers that SOHAY has set up in the capital city. The centers help children go to primary school. They have classes that help them catch up on their education. Once they are old enough to go to school, the children can do homework at the centers with help from other children. Alamin, who is ten years old, used to work in a plastic factory. His father works as a street seller and his mother works as a housewife. They are all happy that he is now able to go to school and work. Rabi says he wants to forget what happened to him in the factory. He says, '' I like school.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: '' We give different store locations to each shopper and rotate them so that they never go back to the same shop within three months, '' said Jill Spencer of '' ABa ''. Each day, they typically spend up to eight hours visiting five to ten stores. Another hour or two is spent filing a detailed report on every part of their visit. The mystery shoppers can earn up to £155 a day. They get money back for their gasoline and hotel stays, and they get money back for their car depreciation ( the shoppers can drive as many as 20,000 miles a year ). title: Vienna Named World’s Top City for Quality of Life
paragraph: A resident of Vienna, Helena Hartlauer, expressed her lack of surprise over the city's top position in the quality of life rankings. The city's social democratic government has a history of investing in high-quality social housing, making Vienna much more affordable than other major cities. "I live in a 100-square-meter apartment from the turn of the century in a good area that is about a 20-minute walk from the city center. But my rent is only €800 (£625) per month." An equivalent apartment in London would cost over £2,000 and even more in New York, which was ranked 44th in the study.

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: According to Professor Sanjiv Singh, who runs a cargo delivery company called NearEarth, piloting a modern drone is like leaving a trail of breadcrumbs: the drone follows instructions to go to a certain altitude, perform a task, and return home. title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: Kenneth Gustafsson, who is in charge of Sweden's most secure prison, Kumla Prison, says that the prison service has changed a lot since he started working there as a young prison officer in 1978. However, he does not think the system has become too soft. In the past, the focus was on treating prisoners humanely, and some people thought they were treated too well. But after some prisoners escaped in 2004, changes were made to improve security. Even though Sweden tries to be humane when sentencing even the most serious offenders, prison terms are usually no longer than ten years. Sweden was the first country in Europe to use electronic tags to monitor criminals and tries to avoid short prison sentences whenever possible by using community-based punishments. These types of punishments have been shown to be more effective at reducing reoffending.

title: Bangladeshi Organization Delivers a Lesson on Ending Child Labor
paragraph: For 14 years, SOHAY, a grassroots non-governmental organization (NGO) funded by the Global Fund for Children and Comic Relief, has been working in slum areas of Dhaka to get child laborers into school. It focuses on children working in hazardous conditions – in aluminum and plastic factories, and tanneries. The classroom is one of 23 urban development centers that SOHAY has set up across the capital. The centers prepare children for primary school with classes that help them catch up on their education. Once they are in primary school, the children can do homework at the centers, with help from their peers. Alamin, ten, who used to work in a plastic factory, attends one of the centers. His father is a street seller and his mother a part-time domestic worker. They are all happy that he’s now in school and away from hazardous work. His friend Rabi says he wants to forget his past in the factory. “I like school,” he says.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: The polygraph is widely used in the US in criminal and other cases and for security clearance for the FBI and CIA but is much less popular in Europe. There has been a lot of skepticism in the scientific and legal communities about its reliability. By contrast, the new method developed by the researchers has performed well in experiments. The basic premise is that liars fidget more and so the use of an all-body motion suit – the kind used in films to create computer-generated characters – will pick this up. One of the research team, Ross Anderson, said: “Decades of deception research show that the interviewer will tell truth from lies only slightly better than random.” He said the new method, by contrast, achieved a reliability rating of over 70%. In some tests, the team has already achieved more than 80%. Anderson said: “The takeaway message is that guilty people fidget more and we can measure this robustly.”

title: Wealth Therapy for the Rich
paragraph: “I shifted towards it naturally,” he said of his becoming an expert in wealth therapy. “Many of the extremely wealthy – the 1% of the 1% – feel that their problems are really not problems. But they are. A lot of therapists do not give enough weight to their issues.” So, what issues are America’s 1% struggling with? “There is guilt over being rich in the first place,” he said. “There is the feeling that they have to hide the fact that they are rich. And, then, there is the isolation – being in the 1%, it turns out, can be lonely.” It seems F. Scott Fitzgerald was right: the very rich “are different from you and me.” Counselors argue things have become worse since the financial crisis and the debate over income inequality that has been spurred on by movements like Occupy Wall Street and the Fight for $15 fair wage campaign.

title: On the Trail of the Wolf
paragraph: The scientist, who is a familiar face on Polish television, says wolves are exceptional animals that are capable of moving up to 30km during a single hunt. “The Beskidy pack is a strong unit, eight or nine individuals. This year, we have recorded five cubs, two yearlings and two adults. We track them using motion-activated cameras in the forest and by following their prints in the mud and snow. In each family group, only one pair reproduces, once a year. All pack members care for the young with solidarity and devotion.” Myslajek, the son of a shepherd, is puzzled by wolves’ bad reputation. “Why does one speak of a 'lone-wolf gunman'? Why did we have to have Little Red Riding Hood, with its big bad wolf?” He is fascinated by these aloof canines who remained in the wild 33,000 years ago when others decided on a much more comfortable existence as domestic dogs.

title: Autumn-Born Children Better at Sports Says Study
paragraph: The research involved 8,550 boys and girls aged between ten and 16 from 26 state schools in Essex. All were tested between 2007 and 2010 on three different measures of fitness: stamina, handgrip strength and lower-body power. The results revealed that a child’s month of birth could make “significant” differences to their levels of cardiovascular fitness, muscle strength and ability to accelerate, all of which predict how good someone is at sports, in which such attributes are vital. Performances at school sports days in the weeks ahead may bear out the findings. November-born children were the fittest overall as they had the most stamina and power and were the second strongest. Those born in October were almost as fit, scoring highest for strength and coming third for power, with December children close behind.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: "We assign different stores to each customer and rotate them so they never return to the same store within three months,” says Jill Spencer of ABa, a mystery shopping company. Each day, they typically spend up to eight hours visiting five to ten stores, plus another hour or two filing detailed reports on every aspect of their visit. They can earn up to £155 a day by doing this. They are also paid for their gas and hotel stay. They are also paid for their car depreciation (they can drive as many as 20,000 miles in a year). Meanwhile, video mystery shoppers, who film their visits with a hidden camera, can earn even more. They can earn around £300 a day.

title: Insects Could be the Planets Next Food Source
paragraph: In March, a BBC documentary will show food writer Stefan Gates looking for and eating locusts and barbecue tarantulas. But behind all the jokes and gimmicks, there is a very serious and serious message. Many experts think it is a good environmental thing for humans to eat creepy-crawlies. The UN's Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has been funding projects since 2011 to help people eat and grow insects in south-east Asia and Africa. An estimated two billion people already eat insects, including caterpillars, as a regular part of their diet. In 2012, the FAO published a list of 1,909 edible species of insect. The Dutch government has sponsored a major international conference on this important food source in 2013.

title: Inky the Octopus Escapes from Aquarium
paragraph: One theory is that Inky slid across the aquarium floor. This would take him three or four meters. Then, he probably felt free and went into a drainpipe that led to the sea. The drainpipe was 50 meters long. It went into the water of Hawke's Bay, on the east coast of New Zealand. Another possible way to escape could have been to squeeze into an open pipe at the top of his tank. This pipe led under the floor. "When we came in the next morning and his tank was empty, I was really surprised," said Yarrell, who has not found Inky yet. The staff and I were pretty sad. title: Japan Calls Time on Long Hours Work Culture
paragraph: Japanese employees are currently entitled to an average 18.5 days’ paid holiday a year. Only two fewer than the global average — with a minimum of 10 days, as well as 15 one-day national holidays. In reality, few come even close to taking their full quota, typically using only nine of their 18.5-day average entitlement. Many British workers regard a two-week summer holiday as an inalienable right, workers in Japan have come to see a four-night vacation as the height of self-indulgence. The move to be debated in the current parliamentary session, comes after companies started encouraging employees to nap on the job to improve their performance. By the end of the decade, the government hopes that, if passed, the law will push Japanese employees toward following the example set by British workers. They use an average of 20 days’ paid annual leave, and those in France, who take an average of 25.

title: On the Trail of the Wolf
paragraph: The scientist, who is a familiar face on Polish television, says wolves are exceptional animals that are capable of moving up to 30km during a single hunt. “The Beskidy pack is a strong unit, eight or nine individuals. This year, we have recorded five cubs, two yearlings and two adults. We track them using motion-activated cameras in the forest and by following their prints in the mud and snow. In each family group, only one pair reproduces, once a year. All pack members care for the young with solidarity and devotion.” Myslajek, the son of a shepherd, is puzzled by wolves’ bad reputation. “Why does one speak of a 'lone-wolf gunman'? Why did we have to have Little Red Riding Hood, with its big bad wolf?” He is fascinated by these aloof canines who remained in the wild 33,000 years ago.

title: Philip Pullman Illegal Downloading Is Moral Squalor
paragraph: “The technical brilliance is so dazzling that people can’t see the moral squalor of what they’re doing,” he writes. “It is outrageous that anyone can steal an artist’s work and get away with it. It is theft, as surely as reaching into someone’s pocket and taking their wallet is theft.” His article comes after music industry leaders met British Prime Minister David Cameron in Downing Street, where the issue of web piracy was discussed. Pullman, writer of the Dark Materials trilogy, says authors and musicians work in poverty for years to bring their work to the level “that gives delight to their audiences and, as soon as they achieve that, the possibility of making a living from it is taken away from them.” He concludes: “The principle is simple, and unaltered by technology, science or magic: if we want to enjoy the work that someone does, we should pay for it.”

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: Professor Sanjiv Singh, who runs a cargo delivery company called NearEarth, said that piloting a state-of-the-art drone was a little more like leaving it a trail of breadcrumbs: go to this altitude, perform this short task, go back home. Even short flights from a mobile landing pad pose serious logistical problems, he said. “They’re not proposing to deliver from one uninhabited place to another uninhabited place; they’re proposing to deliver from a warehouse to where the consumer is, which is likely an urban area,” he said. “There are going to be hazards along the way that the vehicle is going to have to detect. Maybe there will be terrain that the map doesn’t know about. Even then, maybe there’s construction equipment that wasn’t there but is there now. Maybe GPS signals are blocked, in which case it’s going to have an incorrect idea about where it is.”

title: Bangladeshi Organization Delivers a Lesson on Ending Child Labor
paragraph: For 14 years, SOHAY, a grassroots non-governmental organization (NGO) paid for by the Global Fund for Children and Comic relief. It has been working in poor areas of Dhaka to get child laborers into school. It focuses on children working in dangerous conditions, in aluminum and plastic factories. It also focuses on tanneries. The classroom is one of 23 city centers that SOHAY has set up across the capital. The centers prepare children for elementary school with classes that help them catch up on their education. Once they are in elementary school, the children can do homework at the center. They can help from their peers. Alamin, ten, who used to work in a plastic factory, attends one of the centers. His father is a street seller and his mother a part-time job. They are all happy that he’s now in school and away from hazardous work. His friend Rabi says he wants to forget his past in the factory. “I like school,” he says.

title: Bangladeshi Organization Delivers a Lesson on Ending Child Labor
paragraph: For 14 years, SOHAY, a grassroots non-governmental organization (NGO) funded by the Global Fund for Children and Comic relief. It has been working in slum areas of Dhaka to get child laborers into school. It focuses on children working in hazardous conditions – in aluminum and plastic factories, and tanneries. The classroom is one of 23 city development centers that SOHAY has set up across the capital. The centers prepare children for primary school with classes that help them catch up on their education. Once they are in primary school, the children can do homework at the centers, with help from their peers. Alamin, ten, who used to work in a plastic factory, attends one of the centers. His father is a street seller and his mother a part-time domestic worker. They are all happy that he’s now in school and away from hazardous work. title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: Autism is a developmental disorder seen in more than one in 100 people. The condition affects individuals in different ways, but is characterized by difficulties in social interaction and communication. So far, there is no effective treatment for the social problems caused by autism. Researchers at Yale have studied the brain chemical oxytocin as a possible treatment for the social impairments caused by autism. It plays a key role in bonding and trust. Results have been mixed, though: one recent study found no significant benefit for youths given the chemical over several days. But Pelphrey said oxytocin might help the brain learn from social interactions; it would work best when used with therapies that encourage people with autism to engage more socially, he said.

title: Will Drones Soon Be Delivering Packages to Your Doorstep
paragraph: Professor Sanjiv Singh, who works for delivery company NearEarth, said that flying drones is quite simple – you just give it some basic instructions: go to this height, do this short task, go back home. Maybe there will be things that the map doesn’t know about. Maybe there will be construction equipment that wasn’t there but is there now. title: Bangladeshi Organization Delivers a Lesson on Ending Child Labor
paragraph: For 14 years, SOHAY, a grassroots non-profit organization funded by the Global Fund for Children and Comic Relief, has been working in Dhaka's slum areas to provide education to children. title: Why You Should Start Work at 10AM
paragraph: It follows a paper, published in 2014, in which he noted that when children are around ten, their biological wake-up time is about 6.30am; at 16, this rises to 8am; and, at 18, someone you may think of as a lazy teenager actually has a natural waking hour of 9am. The traditional school starting time works for 10-year-olds but not 16- to 18-year-olds. For the older teenagers, it might be more sensible to start the school day at 11am or later. “a 7am alarm call for older adolescents,” Kelley and his team pointed out in the paper, “is the equivalent of a 4.30am start for a teacher in their 50s.”

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: The polygraph is widely used in the US in criminal cases. It is also used to get clearance for the FBI and CIA, but is not very popular in Europe. There has been a lot of skepticism about its reliability in the scientific and legal world. The new method developed by the researchers has worked well in experiments, however. The idea is that liars will fidget more and so the use of an all-body motion suit will pick this up. This is the kind used in movies to make computer-generated characters. One of the research team, Ross Anderson, said : '' Decades of research show that the interviewer will tell truth from lies only slightly better than random. '' He said the new method had a reliability rating of over 70 %. In some tests, the team has already made more than 80 %. Anderson said, '' The takeaway message is that people who are guilty fidget more and we can measure this. ''

"His article comes after leaders of the music industry met British Prime Minister David Cameron in Downing Street to talk about the issue. Pullman, writer of the His Dark Materials trilogy, says authors and musicians work in poverty and obscurity for years to bring their work to the level where people want to read it. When they do, he says, they can no longer make money from it. He says: "The principle is simple, and it does not change technology, science or magic. If we want to enjoy someone's work, we have to pay for it."

title: Bangladeshi Organization Delivers a Lesson on Ending Child Labor
paragraph: For 14 years ago, SOHAY, a grassroots non-governmental organization (NGO) funded by the Global Fund for Children and Comic relief has been working in slum areas of Dhaka to get child laborers into school. It focuses on children working in hazardous conditions – in aluminum and plastic factories and tanneries. The classroom is one of 23 urban development centers that SOHAY has set up across the capital. The centers prepare children for primary school with classes that help them catch up on their education. Once they are in primary school the children can do homework at the centers with help from their peers. Alamin ten who used to work in a plastic factory attends one of the centers. His father is a street seller and his mother a part-time domestic worker. They are all happy that he’s now in school and away from hazardous work. His friend Rabi says he wants to forget his past in the factory. “I like school” he says.

title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: Autism is a developmental disorder seen in more than one in 100 people. The condition affects individuals in different ways but is characterized by difficulties in social interaction and communication. So far there is no effective treatment for the social problems caused by autism. Researchers at Yale have studied the brain chemical oxytocin as a potential treatment for the social impairments caused by autism because it plays a key role in bonding and trust. The results have been mixed, though— one recent study found no significant benefit for youths given the chemical over several days. But Pelphrey said oxytocin might help the brain learn from social interactions; it would work best when used with therapies that encourage people with autism to engage more socially, he said.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: “We assign different store locations to each shopper and rotate them so that they never go back to the same shop within three months,” says Jill Spencer of mystery shopping company Aba. “Each day they typically spend up to eight hours visiting five to ten stores plus another hour or two filing detailed reports on every aspect of their visit.” For that the mystery shoppers can earn up to £155 a day. They are also reimbursed for their gasoline and hotel stays, and compensated for their car depreciation (the shoppers can be expected to drive as many as 20 miles a year. title: Autumn-Born Children Better at Sports Says Study
paragraph: The research involved 8,550 boys and girls between 10 and 16 from 26 state schools in Essex. All were tested between 2007 and 2010 on three different measures of fitness: stamina, handgrip strength and lower-body power. The results revealed that a child’s month of birth could make “significant” differences to their levels of heart fitness, muscle strength and ability to accelerate. All of these results predict how good someone is at sports, in which such attributes are vital. Performances at school sports days in the weeks ahead may bear out the findings. November-born children were the fittest overall as they had the most stamina and power and were the second strongest. Those born in October were almost as fit, scoring highest for strength and coming third for power. December children were close behind.

title: Why is Sweden Closing its Prisons?
paragraph: “The modern prison service in Sweden is very different from when I joined as a young prison officer in 1978,” says Kenneth Gustafsson, governor of Kumla Prison, Sweden’s most secure jail. However, he doesn’t think the system has gone soft. “When I joined, the focus was very much on humanity in prisons. Prisoners were treated well – maybe too well, some might say. However, after a number of high-profile escapes in 2004, we had to make more secure.” The Swedes still managed to maintain a broadly humane approach to sentencing, even of the most serious offenders: jail terms rarely exceed 10 years. Sweden was the first country in Europe to introduce the electronic tagging of convicted criminals. He continues to strive to minimize short-term prison sentences wherever possible by using community-based punishments.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: The polygraph is widely used in the U.S. in criminal and other cases and for security clearance for the FBI and CIA but is much less popular in Europe. There has been a lot of skepticism in the scientific and legal communities about its reliability. By contrast, the new method developed by the researchers has performed well in experiments. The basic premise is that liars fidget more and so the use of an all-body motion suit — the kind used in films to create computer-generated characters. One of the research team, Ross Anderson, said: “Decades of deception research show that the interviewer will tell truth from lies only slightly better than random.” He said the new method, by contrast, achieved a reliability rating of over 70percent. In some tests, the team has already achieved more than 80percent. Anderson said: “The takeaway message is that guilty people fidget more and we can measure this robustly.”

title: John Lewis Christmas Advertisement 2015: Raising Awareness for Age UK
paragraph: After two years of successful ads featuring cuddly animals – a bear and hare, then a penguin – this time, the retailer is tugging at the heartstrings with a story of a young girl, Lily, who spots an old man living in a shack on the moon through her telescope. The determined child tries sending him a letter and firing a note via bow and arrow, before floating him a present of a telescope tied to balloons, which finally enables them to make contact. The ad’s strapline is: “Show someone they’re loved this Christmas,” which echoes Age UK’s own campaign: “No one should have no one at Christmas.” Profits from three products – a mug, gift tag and card – will go to the charity. “The charity really resonates with people at this time of year and the ad lends itself to thinking about someone who lives on your street that might not see anybody,” said Rachel Swift, head of marketing at John Lewis.

title: Love Hormone Helps Autistic Children Bond with Others
paragraph: Autism is a developmental disorder seen in more than one in 100 people. The condition affects individuals in different ways, but is characterized by difficulties in social interaction and communication. So far, there is no effective treatment for the social problems caused by autism. Researchers at Yale have studied the brain chemical oxytocin as a potential treatment for the social impairments caused by autism because it plays a crucial role in bonding and trust. Results have been mixed, though: one recent study found no significant benefit for youths given the chemical over several days. But Pelphrey said oxytocin might help the brain learn from social interactions; it would work best when used with therapies that encourage people with autism to engage more socially, he said.

title: Man Falls Just Short in Patriot Game to be 100% French
paragraph: “Politicians say all sorts of things and expect us to go along with it. He set just three rules for himself: eat only foods produced in France, eliminate contact with foreign-made goods and do so on €1,800 a month (above the minimum wage of €1,430 to cover the extra expense of living in Paris). title: Japan Calls Time on Long Hours Work Culture
paragraph: Japanese employees are currently entitled to an average 18.5 days’ paid holiday a year – only two fewer than the global average – with a minimum of ten days, as well as 15 one-day national holidays. In reality, few come even close to taking their full quota, typically using only nine of their 18.5-day average entitlement. While many British workers regard a two-week summer holiday as an inalienable right, workers in Japan have come to see a four-night vacation as the height of self-indulgence. The move, to be debated in the current parliamentary session, comes after companies started encouraging employees to nap on the job to improve their performance. By the end of the decade, the government hopes that, if passed, the law will push Japanese employees towards following the example set by British workers, who use an average of 20 days’ paid annual leave, and those in France, who take an average of 25.

title: The Secrets of the Mystery Shopper
paragraph: “We assign different store locations to each shopper and rotate them so that they never go back to the same shop within three months,” says Jill Spencer of mystery shopping company ABa. “Each day, they typically spend up to eight hours visiting five to ten stores, plus another hour or two filing detailed reports on every aspect of their visit.” For that, the mystery shoppers can earn up to £155 a day. They are also reimbursed for their gasoline and hotel stays, and compensated for their car depreciation (the shoppers can be expected to drive as many as 20,000 miles a year). Meanwhile, video mystery shoppers, who film their visits with a hidden camera planted in a buttonhole or handbag, can earn even more – around £300 a day.

title: Inky the Octopus Escapes from Aquarium
paragraph: One theory is that Inky slid across the aquarium floor – a journey of three or four meters – and then, sensing freedom was at hand, into a drainpipe that led directly to the sea. The drainpipe was 50 meters long and opened onto the waters of Hawke’s Bay, on the east coast of New Zealand’s North Island. Another possible escape route could have involved Inky squeezing into an open pipe at the top of his tank, which led under the floor to the drain. “When we came in the next morning and his tank was empty, I was really surprised,” said Yarrell, who has not launched a search for Inky. “The staff and I have been pretty sad. But then, this is Inky and he’s always been a bit of a surprise octopus.”

title: Why You Should Start Work at 10AM
paragraph: It follows a paper, published in 2014, in which he noted that, when children are around ten, their biological wake-up time is about 6.30am; at 16, this rises to 8am; and, at 18, someone you may think of as a lazy teenager actually has a natural waking hour of 9am. The conventional school starting time works for 10-year-olds but not 16- to 18-year-olds. For the older teenagers, it might be more sensible to start the school day at 11am or even later. “A 7am alarm call for older adolescents,” Kelley and his colleagues pointed out in the paper, “is the equivalent of a 4.30am start for a teacher in their 50s.”

title: Insects Could be the Planets Next Food Source
paragraph: In March, a BBC documentary will feature food writer Stefan Gates searching out and eating deep-fried locusts and barbecued tarantulas. But, behind all the gimmicks and jokes about flies in the soup, there is a deeply serious message. Many experts believe there is a clear environmental benefit to humans eating creepy-crawlies. The UN’s Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) has been funding projects since 2011 aimed at promoting the eating and farming of insects in south-east Asia and Africa, where an estimated two billion people already eat insects and caterpillar larvae as a regular part of their diet. In 2012, the FAO published a list of 1,909 edible species of insect and, with sponsorship from the Dutch government, plans a major international conference on “this valuable food source” in 2013.

title: Hundreds Hurt after Meteorite Falls to Earth

Mobile phone networks became very slow because of the amount of calls made. The vapor trail could be seen for hundreds of miles around, even in Kazakhstan.

title: Autumn-Born Children Better at Sports Says Study
paragraph: The study examined 8,550 boys and girls aged between ten and 16 from 26 state schools in Essex. Between 2007 and 2010, the researchers tested them on three different measures of fitness: stamina, handgrip strength, and lower-body power. The results showed that a child’s birth month could have a “significant” impact on their cardiovascular fitness, muscle strength, and ability to accelerate. These factors are crucial for sports performance. The research found that November-born children were the fittest overall, with the highest levels of stamina and power and the second-highest strength. Children born in October were almost as fit, scoring highest for strength and third for power, with December children close behind. The findings may be reflected in performances at school sports events in the upcoming weeks.

title: Japan Calls Time on Long Hours Work Culture
paragraph: Japanese workers are allowed to take an average of 18.5 days of paid vacation per year, which is only two days fewer than the global average. The minimum requirement for paid vacation is ten days, and there are also 15 national holidays that workers can take off. However, many workers don't use their full entitlement and only take around nine days of paid vacation on average. In contrast to British workers who commonly take two weeks off during the summer, Japanese workers typically see a four-night vacation as a luxury. The government is considering making it mandatory for workers to take at least five days of paid holiday a year. This move comes as some companies have started encouraging their employees to nap during work hours to increase their productivity. The goal is to increase the number of days Japanese employees take off to match the average of British workers, who take around 20 days of paid vacation per year, and French workers, who take around 25 days.

title: A New Form of Lie Detector Test
paragraph: The polygraph is commonly used in criminal cases and for security clearance by the FBI and CIA in the United States, but it is not as popular in Europe. Many scientists and legal experts have questioned its reliability. However, the researchers who developed the new method have conducted successful experiments. The new method uses an all-body motion suit, similar to those used in films to create computer-generated characters, to detect fidgeting, which is a common sign of lying. Ross Anderson, a member of the research team, explained that previous research showed that interviewers could only detect lies slightly better than random guessing. In contrast, their new method achieved a reliability rating of over 70%, and in some tests, they achieved more than 80%. Anderson concluded that guilty people tend to fidget more, and they can measure this accurately using their new method.

title: Man Falls Just Short in Patriot Game to be 100% French
paragraph: Benjamin Carle wanted to test if it was possible to live solely on products made in France for ten months. He did this as part of a TV documentary after a French minister urged people to buy French to save the country's industrial production sector. Carle followed three rules: he only ate food produced in France, avoided foreign-made goods, and did all this on a budget of €1,800 per month. However, he was surprised to find out that only 4.5% of his belongings were made in France, so he had to get rid of most of them, including his lightbulbs and green beans. Carle aimed to hold politicians accountable for their words and see if what they said was possible to achieve.

title: Bright Future for Astrotourism
paragraph: Fildes reminds his team that their goal is to interact with and entertain people while inspiring them. He is a leader in the astrotourism industry in the UK. In 2013, Northumberland, which includes Hadrian's Wall, Kielder Water, and Forest Park, was granted Dark Sky Park status, the only one in England. Dark Sky Parks are rare and are only given to places that take significant measures to prevent light pollution and have sufficiently dark skies. The International Dark-Sky Association in Arizona grants this status. In Northumberland Dark Sky Park, the area is so dark that even Venus can cast a shadow on the Earth. Only 5% of the UK population can see more than 31 stars on a clear night.

title: On the Trail of the Wolf
paragraph: A scientist who often appears on Polish TV thinks that wolves are amazing animals that can travel up to 30 kilometers in a single hunt. The Beskidy pack is a strong group of eight or nine wolves, and this year they have five cubs, two yearlings, and two adults. The scientist tracks them using motion-activated cameras and by following their footprints in the mud and snow. Only one pair in each family group reproduces once a year, and all pack members take care of the young together. The scientist is confused by the bad reputation of wolves and wonders why they are portrayed as "lone-wolf gunmen" or as the big bad wolf in Little Red Riding Hood. He is fascinated by these wild canines who have been living in the wild for 33,000 years while other dogs have chosen a more comfortable life as domesticated pets.
